revision.text:
{{about|an episode of the TV show ''[[Psych]]''|the spelling competition|spelling bee}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Spellingg Bee | series = [[Psych]] | image =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Spellingg Bee Psych 1-2.jpg|250px]] --> | caption = The introduction of [[Juliet O'Hara]]. The inclusion of Juliet in the episode forced producers to move the installment up to the second in the season, and caused the restructuring of much of the episode's introduction | season = 1 | episode = 2 | writer = [[Steve Franks]] | director = [[Mel Damski]] | airdate = July 14, 2006 | production = 1002<ref name="Page 1">[[#Spellingg Bee|Spellingg Bee (#1_1002)]] p. 1</ref> | length = 43 minutes<ref name="itunes">{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/psych-season-1/id164855161 |title=Psych, Season 1 |work=[[iTunes Store]] |publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]] |accessdate=May 22, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704221705/https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/psych-season-1/id164855161 |archivedate=July 4, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> | guests = * [[Kirsten Nelson]] as Chief [[Karen Vick]] * Kyle Pejpar as Young [[Shawn Spencer]] * Jeremy Loheir as Young [[Burton Guster]] * Alex Bruhanski as Spellmaster Cavanaugh * Issey Lamb as Brandon Vu * [[Alexander Calvert]] as Jiri Prochazka * Richard Zeman as Miklous Prochazka * [[Bud Collins]] as himself<ref name="Credits">[[#Spellingg Bee|Spellingg Bee (#1_1002)]] Credits</ref> | season_article = Psych (season 1) | episode_list = List of Psych episodes | prev = [[Pilot (Psych episode)|Pilot]] | next = [[Speak Now or Forever Hold Your Piece]] }} "'''Spellingg Bee'''", also known as "'''The Spellingg Bee'''", is the [[List of Psych episodes|second episode]] of the [[Psych (season 1)|first season]] of the American [[comedy-drama]] detective television series ''[[Psych]]''. It was written by series creator and co-executive producer [[Steve Franks]], and was directed by co-executive producer and director [[Mel Damski]] during November and December 2005. The episode originally aired on [[USA Network]] in the United States on July 14, 2006 with a rating of [[TV-PG]]. The installment features guest appearances by [[Kirsten Nelson]], [[Alexander Calvert]], Kyle Pejpar, and Jeremy Loheir, among others. It also features an appearance by [[sportscaster]] [[Bud Collins]].
The series follows [[Shawn Spencer]] ([[James Roday]]) and his assistant [[Burton Guster|Burton "Gus" Guster]] ([[Dulé Hill]]), who operate a fake psychic detective agency, which is actually based on Shawn's hyperobservant ability. In the episode, Shawn and Gus are watching a [[spelling bee]] on TV when the expected champion collapses suddenly. Suspecting a set-up, they investigate the bee. While there, the spellmaster (Alex Bruhanski) suspiciously falls over a railing to his death, strengthening their beliefs in foul play. With help from Shawn's father, [[Henry Spencer (Psych)|Henry Spencer]] ([[Corbin Bernsen]]) they discover poison in the spellmaster's meal, confirming their thoughts. Shawn realizes that the entire situation was created by a contestant and his father in order to cover up that they were cheating.
The installment was originally written to be the third episode of the season, but was moved up by the show's producers to introduce the character [[Juliet O'Hara]] earlier. Like most episodes of the series, it was filmed in and around the city of [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada. "Spellingg Bee" received mixed-to-positive reception from television critics. According to [[Nielsen Media Research]], the episode was watched by 4.71 million people during its original broadcast, making up approximately 3.35 million households. It received a 1.5 rating/5 share among viewers in the 18–49 demographic. Actor Dulé Hill was nominated for an award at the 13th NAMIC Vision Awards for his performance in the episode.
==Plot== [[Shawn Spencer]] ([[James Roday]]) buys a newspaper and walks back into a restaurant to find his seat taken. The girl in his seat introduces herself as [[Juliet O'Hara]] ([[Maggie Lawson]]). Shawn realizes she's a cop, and immediately after he does, she and several officers arrest a man at the bar. Later, [[Gus (Psych)|Burton "Gus" Guster]] ([[Dulé Hill]]) is in the Psych office, watching the local spelling bee on TV. Shortly after Shawn enters the office, expected spelling bee champion Brandon Vu (Issey Lamb) collapses, to the shock of the audience. Shawn notices something wrong with Vu's inhaler, and realizes that Vu was intentionally harmed. They receive a phone call from interim police chief [[Karen Vick]] ([[Kirsten Nelson]]) asking them to investigate the bee. They interview Vu at the hospital, who tells them that his inhaler was not working during the competition. They begin individual interviews with the competitors, but discover no leads. While they are waiting between interviews, spellmaster Cavanaugh (Alex Bruhanski) experiences chest pain and falls over a railing to his death, in front of Shawn and Gus. The police write off his death as a heart attack; Shawn and Gus are skeptical, and break into Cavanaugh's booth to investigate.<ref name="Page 1"/>
Gus finds Cavanaugh's lunch, and believes that it is poisoned due to its unusual smell. Shawn takes it to his father, [[Henry Spencer (Psych)|Henry Spencer]] ([[Corbin Bernsen]]), to have it analyzed. Henry demands that in return, Shawn must build a dog house he promised to make in 1989. Shawn agrees, and leaves. While riding back to the office, he is run off the road by a mysterious van. Shawn wakes up in the hospital, and after he gets out, Gus informs him that he discovered another fake inhaler. Shawn returns to Henry's house to finish the dog house. Henry confirms that the lunch was poisoned, and Shawn returns to the bee. He disguises himself as the new spellmaster in order to enter the booth, and discovers that Cavanaugh had found out that Miklous Prochazka (Richard Zeman) was helping his son (Alexander Calvert), a contestant in the bee, to cheat by spelling out his son's words to him in [[Morse code]] using electrical impulses that were transferred to his false inhaler. After the bee has finished, Shawn has a "psychic vision" where he reveals everything to the police, who arrest Miklous and his son.<ref name="Page 2">[[#Spellingg Bee|Spellingg Bee (#1_1002)]] p. 2</ref>
==Production==
===Cast and crew=== [[File:Steve Franks cropped image Comic con.png|thumb|right|150px|[[Steve Franks]] wrote the episode, his second work on the show|alt=An image of a man in a black shirt looking to his left]] "Spellingg Bee" was the first episode directed by co-executive producer and director [[Mel Damski]].<ref name="Star">{{cite web |author=Staff |year=2006 |url=http://www.starpulse.com/Television/Psych/Episode_Guides/episode/4935935/ |title=Spellingg Bee |work=Psych Episode Guides |publisher=Starpulse |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921062357/http://www.starpulse.com/Television/Psych/Episode_Guides/episode/4935935/ |archivedate=September 21, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The episode was the second installment written by co-executive producer and creator [[Steve Franks]], after the previous episode "[[Pilot (Psych episode)|Pilot]]".<ref name="Sun">{{Cite news |last=Asman |first=Amy |date=October 13, 2009 |title=Welcome to Santa Barbara-Psych! |url=http://www.santamariasun.com/cover/3139/welcome-to-santa-barbarapsych/ |newspaper=Santa Maria Sun |page=1 |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref><ref name="episode1">{{cite episode |title=[[Pilot (Psych episode)|Pilot]] |series=Psych |serieslink=Psych |credits=[[Michael Engler]] (director); [[Steve Franks]] (writer) |network=[[USA Network]] |airdate=July 7, 2006 |season=1 |number=1}}</ref> Tracey Jeffery was the episode's producer, John J. Sakmar and Jerry Lenhart were the consulting producers, and Mel Damski, Steve Franks, Kelly Kulchak, and Chris Henze were the associate producers. Erin Smith was the production manager. Tracy Hillman was the installment's associate producer, and Michael McMurray was the director of photography, while Allan Lee and Anupam Nigam acted as the editors. David Crabtree, James Ilecic, Allan Lee, and Gordon Rempel were the script editors. The music for the episode was written by Adam Cohen and John Robert Wood. Assistant directors for the installment were Jack Hardy and Roger Russell.<ref name="Closing Credits">{{cite AV media |title=Closing credits for "Spellingg Bee": [[Psych (season 1)|Psych, The Complete First Season]] |publisher=NBCUniversal |date=2006 |medium=DVD |people=[[Mel Damski]] (director); [[Steve Franks]] (writer)}}</ref><ref name="TV Year Volume 1">{{cite book |last=Muir |first=John Kenneth |year=2007 |title=TV Year, Volume 1: The Prime Time 2005-2006 Season |location=[[New York City]] |publisher=[[Applause Theatre and Cinema Books]] |page=111 |chapter=Part 1: New TV Series |isbn=978-1-55783-684-7}}</ref>
The episode was originally planned to be the third installment of the season, but was moved up by the show's producers in order to introduce the major character [[Juliet O'Hara]], played by [[Maggie Lawson]]. The scene introducing O'Hara was filmed as part of the fourth episode, "[[Woman Seeking Dead Husband: Smokers Okay, No Pets]]", but was added to the installment because of the need to bring in the character. It was also used for Lawson's audition for the show.<ref name="begin 037">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 0:37–2:45</ref> Kyle Pejpar and Jeremy Loheir were cast to play Young Shawn and Young Gus in the episode. The show's casting directors brought in the actors because older versions of young Shawn and Gus were needed for the flashback scenes in the episode. Sportscaster [[Bud Collins]] guest starred in the episode. Collins wrote all of his dialogue, and designed his own wardrobe for the installment.<ref name="begin 432">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 4:32–6:26</ref>
In addition, another guest star for the episode was [[Kirsten Nelson]], who played interim police [[Karen Vick|chief Karen Vick]], a major reoccurring character who first premiered in the episode "Pilot".<ref name="episode1"/> Shortly before the installment was filmed, Kirsten Nelson gave birth to her daughter, which would later be portrayed in the episode "[[Shawn vs. the Red Phantom]]".<ref name="begin 2909">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 29:09–29:51</ref><ref name="episode8">{{cite episode |title=[[Shawn vs. the Red Phantom]] |series=Psych |serieslink=Psych |credits=[[John T. Kretchmer]] (director); Anupam Nigam (writer) |network=[[USA Network]] |airdate=August 25, 2006 |season=1 |number=8}}</ref> Other minor guests included Alex Bruhanski (who played Spellmaster Cavanaugh), Issey Lamb (who played Brandon Vu), [[Alexander Calvert]] (who played Jiri Prochazka), Richard Zeman (who played Miklous Prochazka), and Brendan Beiser (who played the bee's color commentator).<ref name="Spell Yahoo">{{cite web |author=Staff |year=2013 |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/shows/psych/episodes/spellingg-bee.html# |title=Ep 2: Spellingg Bee |publisher=[[Yahoo! Inc.]] |work=[[Yahoo! TV]] |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref>
===Writing and filming=== {{Quote box |quote = Steve Franks and his wife, April, went to Santa Barbara on their honeymoon. At the time, he was developing the idea for Psych. He knew he didn't want a big city atmosphere. He wanted a place that was beautiful. |source = [[Mel Damski]], speaking on the decision for the filming location of ''Psych''.<ref name="Sun"/> |width = 35% |align = right |quoted = 1 }} The show is meant to take place in the [[Southern California]] city of [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]]; however, most of the series is filmed in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], and the surrounding communities. The majority of the scenes are filmed in the suburb community of [[White Rock, British Columbia|White Rock]], especially those including the ocean or coastline.<ref name="Pilot Commentary">{{cite AV media |last=Franks |first=Steve |last2=Henze |first2=Chris |last3=Kulchak |first3=Kelly |title="Domestic Pilot" Audio Commentary: Psych, The Complete First Season |publisher=Universal Studios |medium=DVD |year=2006}}</ref> Speaking about filming the show, Steve Franks stated that "I swear it's San Clemente, CA. It couldn't look more like it". In order to make the sets appear as Santa Barbara, the show's crew members installed many props stereotypical to Southern California, including fake palm trees, surfboards, and the California-published newspaper, the ''Santa Maria Sun''. The production crew had to truck in eight palm trees to each set during filming.<ref name="Sun"/><ref name="Goldman 2">[[#Goldman|Goldman (2006)]], p. 2</ref>
Several of the show's filming sets were changed between episodes. The Psych office was expanded and refurnished, afterwards becoming the second largest stage for the show.<ref name="begin 712">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 7:12–8:46</ref> The house for Henry Spencer was changed, in order to be closer to the ocean. The set for Chief Vick's office was also changed, and was repainted to brighten the scenes shot in it.<ref name="begin 2741">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 27:41–28:00</ref> Much of the episode was filmed on a sound stage, while several other scenes were filmed in the basement of the facility.<ref name="begin 2244">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 22:44–22:58</ref> Much of the installment was written to take place in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]]'s [[Arlington Theater]].<ref name="begin 1457">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 14:57–15:30</ref> Several of the episode's scenes were written by Franks while filming the pilot episode.<ref name="begin 3045">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 30:45–30:52</ref>
In order to make the show seem more realistic, Franks and other writers talked to his father, a former [[Los Angeles Police Department|Los Angeles police officer]], and several psychics. Much of the episode's content was improvised by the actors, and Roday included a pineapple in the episode, continuing the reoccurring theme on the show.<ref name="Pilot Commentary"/><ref name="Creative Freedom">{{cite news |last=Atkin |first=Hillary |title=‘Psych’s’ James Roday, Dule Hill Savor Series’ Creative Freedom |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/features/psych_james_roday_dule_hill-1200327235/ |accessdate=September 1, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=March 26, 2013 |oclc=60626272 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922165054/http://variety.com/2013/tv/features/psych_james_roday_dule_hill-1200327235/ |archivedate=September 22, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> James Roday talked to producers about including singing in the series' second episode, but the idea was shut down because it was too soon in the show. In addition, Steve Franks considered writing one of the show's early episodes to be about a psychic claiming Shawn was a fraud, but delayed writing the episode until later.<ref name="Pilot Commentary"/><ref name="Goldman 3">[[#Goldman|Goldman (2006)]], p. 3</ref> The producers attempted to include themes against smoking and the issues of friendship. Franks also included a character named Mrs. Foote, a reference to his 1999 movie ''[[Big Daddy (1999 film)|Big Daddy]]''.<ref name="begin 3548">[[#Commentary|Franks et al.]], 35:48–36:06</ref>
==Release== The episode was originally broadcast in the United States on July 14, 2006, on [[USA Network]] as the second episode of the show's first season.<ref name="MSN">{{cite web |author=Staff |year=2013 |url=http://tv.msn.com/tv/episode/psych/spelling-bee/ |title=Spellingg Bee |work=Psych–Episode Info |publisher=[[MSN TV]] |accessdate=June 6, 2013}}</ref> It aired at a 10:00 P.M. [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]]/[[Pacific Standard Time|PST]] time slot, following a new episode of the show ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]''.<ref name="itunes"/><ref name="Monk Returns">{{cite news |last=Cox |first=Ted |date=July 7, 2006 |url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-148064713/of-psychics-and-psychiatry-monk-returns-to-form |title=Of Psychics and Psychiatry 'Monk' Returns to Form and Gets a Quirky New USA Running Mate in 'Psych' |newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]] |location=[[Arlington Heights, Illinois|Arlington Heights, IL]] |page=35 |oclc=18030507 |accessdate=September 7, 2013 |via=[[Questia]]}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> The episode aired under a rating of [[TV-PG]], meaning that some of its content may not be appropriate for young children.<ref name="TVGuide">{{cite web |author=Staff |year=2006 |url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/psych-2006/episode-2-season-1/spelling-bee/281392 |title=Psych Episode: "Spelling Bee" |work=Psych Episodes on USA |publisher=[[TV Guide]] |accessdate=May 22, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927112448/http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/psych-2006/episode-2-season-1/spelling-bee/281392 |archivedate=September 27, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The show's previous installment, "Pilot", was a special extended episode, running for approximately 66 minutes. "Spellingg Bee" was the first installment of the show to run for a normal length, approximately 43 minutes.<ref name="itunes"/><ref name="IGN Broadcast">{{cite web |last=Zoromski |first=Brian |date=June 26, 2006 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/06/27/what-2-watch-627-71006?page=11 |title=What 2 Watch: 6/27 - 7/10/06 |work=[[IGN TV]] |publisher=IGN |page=11 |accessdate=September 24, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927083749/http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/06/27/what-2-watch-627-71006?page=11 |archivedate=September 27, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> The [[National Broadcasting Corporation]] (NBC), parent company of ''Psych'''s producer, [[Universal Cable Productions]], rebroadcast several of the show's episodes, due to struggling ratings for the network.<ref name="Pittsburgh">{{cite news |last=Owen |first=Rob |date=July 22, 2006 |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/ae/tv/tuned-in-greys-anatomy-vs-csi-just-what-the-creator-ordered-443125/ |title=Tuned In: 'Grey's Anatomy' vs. 'CSI' just what the creator ordered |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |issn=1068-624X |accessdate=September 24, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928012004/http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/ae/tv/tuned-in-greys-anatomy-vs-csi-just-what-the-creator-ordered-443125/ |archivedate=September 28, 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Futon 1">{{cite web |author=[[NBC]] |date=July 21, 2006 |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2006/07/21/nbc-getting-psyched-for-mondays-in-august-with-re-broadcasts-of-new-usa-network-hit-series-psych-on-august-7-and-14-21854/20060721nbc07/ |title=NBC Getting 'Psyched' for Mondays in August with Re-Broadcasts of New USA Network Hit Series, 'Psych' on August 7 and 14 |work=Breaking News |publisher=The Futon Critic |accessdate=September 24, 2013}}</ref> The re-airing of the episodes occurred on August 7 and August 14 of 2006; "Spellingg Bee" was shown at an 8:00 P.M. time slot, on August 7.<ref name="Futon Re-air">{{cite web |author=Staff |year=2006 |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/listings/20060731nbc01/ |title=Psych [Program Change] |work=Listings{{ndash}}By Air Date |publisher=The Futon Critic |accessdate=September 24, 2013}}</ref>
"Spellingg Bee", along with the fourteen other episodes from ''Psych's'' [[Psych (season 1)|first season]] were released on a four-disc [[DVD]] set in the United States and Canada on June 26, 2007. The set includes full audio commentaries for six episodes, including "Spellingg Bee", [[deleted scene]]s for most episodes, blooper reals, audition tapes, character profiles, the international version of the episode "[[Pilot (Psych episode)|Pilot]]", an "Inside the writers' room" featurette, and other special features. The set is filmed in [[Aspect ratio (image)#16:9 standard|1.78:1 aspect ratio]], with English subtitles available, and [[Dolby Digital]] 5.1 Surround.<ref name="DVD Shows 1">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Psych-Complete-1st-Season/6573 |title=Psych — The Complete 1st Season |accessdate=May 31, 2013 |work=[[TVShowsonDVD.com]] |publisher=[[TV Guide|TV Guide Online]] |year=2007 |author=Staff |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921100620/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Psych-Complete-1st-Season/6573 |archivedate=September 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Lining">{{cite DVD notes |title=Psych, The Complete First Season |others=[[Steve Franks]], et al. |type=booklet |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]] |location=[[New York City]] |year=2007}}</ref> The DVD set was released in the [[United Kingdom]] and other [[DVD region codes|Region 2]] countries on January 9, 2008, and was released in [[Australia]] on April 30 of the same year.<ref name="Amazon 1">{{cite web|author=Staff |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Psych-Season-DVD-James-Roday/dp/B000XPUAQQ/ref=sr_1_1?s=dvd&ie=UTF8&qid=1369342347&sr=1-1&keywords=Psych+season+1 |title=Psych - Season 1 [DVD] |publisher=[[Amazon.co.uk]] |accessdate=May 23, 2013}}</ref><ref name="EzyDVD">{{cite web |author=Staff |url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/DVD/psych-the-complete-1st-season-4-disc-set/dp/798862 |title=Psych - The Complete 1st Season (4 Disc Set) |publisher=[[EzyDVD]] |accessdate=May 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101061142/http://www.ezydvd.com.au/DVD/psych-the-complete-1st-season-4-disc-set/dp/798862 |archivedate=November 1, 2013 |df= }}</ref> The entire first season has also been released on the [[iTunes]] store for digital download, as well as independent downloads of each individual episode.<ref name="itunes"/>
==Reception== [[File:Maggie Lawson2010.jpg|thumb|right|The importance of [[Maggie Lawson]]'s character [[Juliet O'Hara]] was questioned from the beginning|alt=A woman in a grey shirt sitting behind a microphone]]
===Ratings=== According to the [[Nielsen Media Research]], in its original American broadcast, "Spellingg Bee" was viewed by a total of 4.71 million people. Approximately 3.35 million households were watching the installment during its initial broadcast.<ref name="AP Ratings">{{cite news |author=[[The Associated Press]] |date=July 19, 2006 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1Y1-95734582.html |title=Ratings for Cable Networks |newspaper=The Associated Press Online |publisher=[[HighBeam Research]] |accessdate=June 6, 2013 |oclc=464378787}} {{subscription required}}</ref> The episode earned a 1.5 rating/5 share in the 18–49 demographic, meaning that on average 1.5 percent of all television-equipped households were tuned into the installment at any given moment, while 5 percent of households watching TV were tuned into it during the time slot.<ref name="Variety Ratings">{{cite news |last=Kissel |first=Rick |title=Fox writes ratings script |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-149069474.html |accessdate=June 6, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=July 19, 2006 |oclc=60626272}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Approximately 1.8 million people in 25–54 demographic also viewed the episode. The installment was the most watched basic cable program for its air date.<ref name="Futon">{{cite web |author=Staff |date=July 18, 2006 |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2006/07/18/usa-network-number-1-across-the-board-21820/20060718usa01/ |title=USA Network #1 Across Board |work=Breaking News |publisher=The Futon Critic |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> "Spellingg Bee" was ranked eighth in total viewers in the week of July 10–16, falling slightly behind its lead-in program, ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]'', which was viewed by 4.89 million people.<ref name="AP Ratings"/> The installment's ratings were a major drop from the show's previous episode, "Pilot", which was viewed by 6.06 million people, and had a 1.9 rating/6 share.<ref name="BC">{{cite news |last=Becker |first=Anne |date=July 11, 2006 |url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/104915-USA_s_Psych_Nabs_Record_Ratings.php |title=USA's Psych Nabs Record Ratings |newspaper=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |ISSN=1068-6827 |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Variety Ratings Pilot">{{cite news |last=Kissel |first=Rick |title=Talent skeins boost nets |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-149558076.html |accessdate=June 6, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=July 12, 2006 |oclc=60626272}} {{subscription required}}</ref> "Spellingg Bee" finished fourth in viewership for ''Psych's'' first season, falling behind the pilot, "[[Weekend Warriors (Psych)|Weekend Warriors]]" (4.76 million),<ref name="Warriors rat">{{cite news |author=Staff Writer |title=Nielsen ratings report |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-151323927.html |accessdate=October 12, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 16, 2006 |oclc=60626272}} {{subscription required}}</ref> and "[[9 Lives (Psych)|9 Lives]]" (4.72 million).<ref name="Lives rat">{{cite news |last=Kissel |first=Rick |title=Football's a hit for NBC |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-150583504.html |accessdate=October 12, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=August 9, 2006 |oclc=60626272}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== Since airing, the episode has received mixed to positive reviews. In his review for [[IGN]], contributor Colin Moriarty heavily criticized the episode, calling it "unintentionally lackluster".<ref name="IGN"/> While Moriarty considered Hill to portray Gus well, he considered Juliet O'Hara and Carlton Lassiter's characters "rather forgettable" and stated that "neither character has any traits that make them interesting in the least".<ref name="IGN"/> He considered the show to be "admittedly in a difficult spot".<ref name="IGN"/> Moriarty criticized the show's police force, calling it "possibly miscast".<ref name="IGN"/> He called the episode "mildly entertaining and mildly boring" and that the show is "not looking too good".<ref name="IGN">{{cite web |last=Moriarty |first=Colin |date=July 17, 2006 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/07/17/psych-spellingg-bee-review |title=Psych: "Spellingg Bee" Review |publisher=[[IGN]] TV |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> The installment was given a rating of 6, or "okay", tying it for the lowest rated episode of the season, with the following episode, "[[Speak Now or Forever Hold Your Piece]]".<ref name="IGN 2">{{cite web |author=Staff |date=March 2007 |url=http://www.ign.com/tv/psych/1 |title=Psych Preview—Season 01 |work=Psych–Show Highlights |publisher=IGN TV |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> In an article for ''[[The New York Times]]'', journalist Bill Carter mentions that after just the two episodes, "USA Network seems to have found another drama hit with 'Psych'".<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |last=Carter |first=Bill |date=July 17, 2006 |title=NBC Keeps Fingers Crossed for 'America's Got Talent' |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=E4 |ISSN=0362-4331}}</ref>
In his review for [[TV Squad]], writer Richard Keller gave the episode a mixed to positive review, calling the installment "pretty unique",<ref name="AOL"/> but that it also had its flaws. He enjoyed the fact that the episode revealed the relationship between Shawn and Henry, that it "reflects the relationship many of us have with our own fathers".<ref name="AOL"/> He also enjoyed the "fleshing out" of Gus's character, that "we now see Gus as quite the brainiac" and "rather than saying nothing but 'No, Shawn'... Gus actually contributes quite a bit to this episode".<ref name="AOL"/> However, Keller also criticized parts of the episode, saying that he disliked the "whole fake psychic concept".<ref name="AOL"/> Keller also criticized Timothy Omundson's character Carlton Lassiter, saying "he just doesn't fit into the whole show", and "Omundson's makes Lassiter look like a cartoon character".<ref name="AOL">{{cite news |last=Keller |first=Richard |date=July 15, 2006 |url=http://www.aoltv.com/2006/07/15/psych-spellingg-bee/ |title=Psych: Spellingg Bee |newspaper=[[TV Squad]] |publisher=[[AOL TV]] |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> In a comment for [[TV Guide]], the show was called "a diamond in the rough", and writer Matt Roush called star [[James Roday]] "a delight".<ref name="TV Guide review">{{cite web |last=Roush |first=Matt |date=July 21, 2006 |url=http://www.tvguide.com/roush/Thanks-24995.aspx |title=Thanks so much for your ... |work=What's Hot |publisher=TV Guide |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> The episode was included in [[Yahoo! TV]]'s list of the nerdiest episodes of Psych. Reviewer Tucker Cummings said that "the wordplay in this episode great" and that "it gives you a great insight into how Gus and Shawn's friendship has functioned (or dysfunctioned) over the years".<ref name="Nerdiest"/> In addition, she said that the episode's murder-mystery plot "is actually really engrossing" when compared to later episodes of the show.<ref name="Nerdiest">{{cite news |last=Cummings |first=Tucker |date=January 17, 2012 |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/nerdiest-episodes-psych-223700627.html |title=The Nerdiest Episodes of 'Psych' |newspaper=Yahoo! TV |publisher=Yahoo! Inc. |accessdate=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
In a review of the [[Syfy]] channel series ''[[Eureka (U.S. TV series)|Eureka]]'', ''[[Boston Globe]]'' critic Matthew Gilbert compared the series to ''Psych'', describing both as having "light-hearted [[comedy-drama|dramedic]] tones".<ref name="Boston Globe">{{cite news |last=Gilbert |first=Matthew |date=July 18, 2006 |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2006/07/18/sci_fi_takes_quirks_to_nth_degree_in_eureka/ |title=Sci Fi takes quirks to nth degree in 'Eureka' |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |ISSN=0743-1791 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref> A few days after the episode aired, Virginia Rohan of ''[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]]'' called the show a "promising series".<ref name="The Record">{{cite news |last=Rohan |first=Virginia |date=July 16, 2006 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-126419559.html |title=Why we love our cop shows |newspaper=[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]] |OCLC=10806291 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> Several critics compared the episode and show to the then-new [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] network series [[Angela's Eyes]]; in his article for the ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]]'', journalist David Kronke stated that "Lifetime's new crime drama 'Angela's Eyes' is essentially the USA Network's new series 'Psych' inside out and played without laughs".<ref name="LA">{{cite news |last=Kronke |first=David |date=July 16, 2006 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9099220.html |title=Liars can run, but they can't hide from Angela's 'Eyes' |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |ISSN=0458-3035 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}} {{subscription required}}</ref> In an article for the [[Akron Beacon Journal]], ''Angela's Eyes'' main character Abigail Spencer was compared to Shawn Spencer, who was described as being "so good that people don't believe what he can figure out".<ref name="Akron">{{cite news |author=Heldenfels, R.D. |date=July 16, 2006 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-148242676.html |title=Abigail Spencer is an FBI agent working with Joe Cobden (left) and... |newspaper=[[Akron Beacon Journal]] |OCLC=34332280 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}} {{Subscription required}}</ref> ''Psych'' was also described as having "a much simpler premise", but being more entertaining than ''Angela's Eyes".<ref name="Akron"/>
The installment has been very positively received by the show's cast and crew. Series creator Steve Franks was asked by [[iTunes]] in 2009 to select his twelve favorite episodes to be put on a special DVD release. The collection, titled ''Psych: Twelve Episodes That Will Make You Happy'', contained four episodes from the first season, including "Spellingg Bee". When describing the episode, Franks stated that "The Spellingg Bee has my one of my favorite scenes in the run of the show when Shawn takes over for the spellmaster and has to investigate a murder while making up words for the contestants to spell".<ref name="12 Episodes">{{cite AV media |people=Franks, Steve |year=2009 |title=Psych: Twelve Episodes That Will Make You Happy |medium=Compilation DVD |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/psych-twelve-episodes-that/id303370528 |accessdate=September 26, 2013 |publisher=[[Universal Network Television|Universal Network Television LLC]] |location=[[Universal City, California]]}}</ref> In 2013, iTunes asked stars James Roday and Dulé Hill to select their 20 favorite episodes from the show. The DVD collection was titled ''Psych: James and Dule's Top 20'', with "Spellingg Bee" was selected as #14 on the collection, picked by Roday. Three other episodes from the first season were also selected.<ref name="20 Favorite">{{cite AV media |people=Hill, Dulé; Roday, James |date=February 25, 2013 |title=Psych: James and Dule's Top 20 |medium=Compilation DVD |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/psych-james-and-dules-top-20/id601610288 |accessdate=September 26, 2013 |publisher=Universal Network Television LLC |location=Universal City, California}}</ref>
===Accolades=== For his performance in portraying Burton "Gus" Guster in the episode, [[Dulé Hill]] was nominated to win the award for "Best Actor–Comedy" at the 13th Annual NAMIC Vision Awards. The awards are organized by the National Association for Multi-ethnicity in Communications (NAMIC), and are given for "outstanding achievements in original, multi-ethnic cable programming".<ref name="NAMIC">{{cite press release|author=Staff |date=January 23, 2007 |url=http://www.namic.com/press/pressreleases/NAMICVANomsRls012307_FINAL.pdf |title=Showtime Networks Leads Nominations for 13th Annual NAMIC Vision Awards |publisher=National Association for Multi-ethnicity in Communications |accessdate=June 7, 2013 |page=2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525033743/http://www.namic.com/press/pressreleases/NAMICVANomsRls012307_FINAL.pdf |archivedate=May 25, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Other nominees for the award were [[Carlos Mencia]], [[Romany Malco]], and [[Damon Wayans]].<ref name="NAMIC News">{{cite news |author=Staff |date=March 26, 2007 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-161021397.html |title=And the Nominees Are … |newspaper=[[Multichannel News]] |ISSN=0276-8593 |accessdate=June 7, 2013}} {{subscription required}}</ref> Hill lost the award to Mencia, for received it for his performance in the [[Comedy Central]] program ''[[Mind of Mencia]]''.<ref name="NAMIC After">{{cite web |last=Duggan |first=Beth |year=2007 |url=http://www.tvweek.com/news/2007/03/showtime_mtv_top_namic_vision.php |title=Showtime, MTV Top NAMIC Vision Awards |work=In Depth |publisher=TV Week |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref>

{{Other uses}} [[File:Children and Youth Sports School in Sevastopol 2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Sports school in [[Sevastopol]]]] A '''sports school''' ({{lang-ru|Детско-Юношеская Спортивная Школа, ДЮСШ}}) is a type of educational institution for children that originated in the [[Soviet Union]]. Sports schools were the basis of the powerful system of physical culture (fitness) and sports education in the USSR and the [[Eastern Bloc]], particularly [[East Germany]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Faupel|first1=Sarah|title=Germany's elite schools nurture sports stars in the making |url=http://www.dw.com/en/germanys-elite-schools-nurture-sports-stars-in-the-making/a-5938501|accessdate=4 June 2017|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=29 August 2010|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hersh|first1=Philip|title=Some of the Elements of the Disgraced East German Sports Machine Remain Part of the Training Culture of the United Nation|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-09-12/sports/0009120168_1_east-german-sports-sports-research-center-berlin-wall|accessdate=4 June 2017|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=12 September 2000|language=en}}</ref> The main features of this system remain in the system of sports education in [[Russia]] and other post-Soviet states, and also became the basis of similar systems in other countries, one of the most powerful ones at the present time being that of the [[People's Republic of China]].<ref name="Rev">[http://www.buzzle.com/editorials/11-9-2004-61432.asp Sam Wollaston on China's Sports Schools]</ref> Many legendary athletes, such as [[Nikolai Andrianov]], [[Nellie Kim]], [[Alexander Popov (swimmer)|Alexander Popov]], [[Viktor Krovopuskov]], [[Vladislav Tretiak]], [[Valeri Kharlamov]], [[Anatoly Alyabyev]] and [[Sergey Bubka]] started their path to [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] success from Soviet sports schools.
==Establishment and early years== The system of sports schools was founded in the 1930s. In 1934, [[Young Pioneers Stadium]] was built in [[Moscow]], the first specialized sports extracurricular institution in the USSR. In the same year the first children's collective was established by [[Dynamo (sports society)|Dynamo sports society]]; this was a prototype of sports schools by [[Voluntary Sports Societies of the USSR|sports societies]].<ref>[http://dynamo.org.ru/history/99.html Ого Вфсо "Динамо" - Всероссийское Физкультурно-Спортивное Общество "Динамо"<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220165626/http://dynamo.org.ru/history/99.html |date=2008-02-20 }}</ref>
In 1935-1936, the first sports schools were opened in Moscow, [[Leningrad]] and other cities of the USSR; they were created and functioned on the basis of regulations, approved by the Central Soviet of Sports Societies and Organizations of the USSR.<ref>[http://www.educom.ru/ru/publications/press/system/review.php Хрнпхвеяйхи Нагнп Бнгмхймнбемхъ Х Пюгбхрхъ Яхярелш Бмеьйнкэмнцн Напюгнбюмхъ Б Лняйбе - Деоюпрюлемр Напюгнбюмхъ Ц. Лняйбш<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> By the 1940s dozens of schools functioned in the USSR by [[Dynamo (sports society)|Dynamo sports society]], [[Spartak (sports society)|Spartak sports society]], [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CDKA]], sports societies of Trade Unions, [[OSOAVIAKHIM]] and in the system of education. After the [[Great Patriotic War]], sports schools were frequently reorganized, transferred from the jurisdiction of sports societies to that of the system of education and vice versa.
Separate from these were two national sports universities under government operation: the Leningrad and Moscow Sports Institutes, which were the major sports institutions for adult level national athletes.
==Olympic Reserve specialized (complex) schools== After the USSR joined as a full member of the [[International Olympic Committee]] in 1951, Specialized Children and Youth (Sports) Schools of the Olympic Reserve ({{lang-ru|Специализированная Детско-Юношеская (Спортивная) Школа Олимпийского Резерва, СДЮ(С)ШОР}}) began to be opened to prepare young athletes for the sports of highest achievements. The number of such sports schools grew, as did the number of sports disciplines within sports schools. They included not only [[Olympic sports]], but also national sports disciplines as well as tourism, [[orienteering]], and other sports. As an alternative there is also Complex Specialized Children and Youth School of the Olympic Reserve ({{lang-uk|Комплексна Спеціалізована Дитячо-Юнацька Школа Олімпійського Резерву, КСДЮШОР}}).
==Schools of Higher Sports Mastery== Aside of regular sports schools and specialized schools of Olympic Reserve, there are also schools of higher sports mastery ({{lang-uk|Школа вищої спортивної майстерності, ШВСМ}}).
== Regional boarding schools of sports profile (Schools of Olympic Reserve) ==
Before 1989 in the Soviet Union existed a network of regional boarding schools of sports profile ({{lang-ru|ОШИСП, Областная школа-интернат спортивного профиля}}).<ref name=fiskalov>Fiskalov, V. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=61v3CwAAQBAJ&pg=PT401&lpg=PT401&dq=%D0%9E%D0%A8%D0%98%D0%A1%D0%9F&source=bl&ots=1tivxxnwZs&sig=-L-j0EU0BvhDVvgcD6qBOgdXt-Y&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4p9qgmYraAhWJ24MKHdDjA0cQ6AEIQDAD#v=onepage&q=%D0%9E%D0%A8%D0%98%D0%A1%D0%9F&f=false Theoretical foundations and organization of athlete training (Теоретические основы и организация подготовки спортсменов)''. Litres, 2017</ref> Children live, study and receive advanced sports training there. Sports boarding schools can be either one-sport-oriented or multisports. In those schools children spend most of their time off studying practicing sports or perfecting certain skills. In 1989 all sports boarding schools were converted to schools of Olympic Reserve, UOR ({{lang-ru|училище олимпийского резерва, УОР}}).<ref name=fiskalov/>
==Structure== Sports schools were compatible with the administrative division of the country: there were District, City, Oblast, Central, Republican sports schools. To enter sports school, a child could have a recommendation from one's secondary school; children were also invited to come into a certain sports school for the selection during lessons in an ordinary school, or they could come for the selection on their own initiative. In accordance with specifics of different sports disciplines, the age of children and youth admitted into a sports school was between 8 and 14. Groups were organized according to [[Unified Sports Classification System of the USSR|ranks of athletes]]: there were separate groups for Second-Class Junior Sportsmen, First-Class Junior Sportsmen, Second-Class Sportsmen, First-Class Sportsmen, Candidates for Master of Sports of the USSR, Masters of Sports of the USSR. Term of study in each group was one to two years, with different sports normatives applied in each year.<ref name="GSE"/>
==Popularity== By 1971 there were 3,813 sports schools in the USSR, with some 1.3 million children and youth training there. These included 2,434 schools with one million attendees under the jurisdiction of the system of education and 1,245 schools with 340,000 attendees functioning in the system of sports societies.<ref name="GSE">[[Great Soviet Encyclopedia]], 3rd ed., [http://slovari.yandex.ru/dict/bse/article/00022/84400.htm entry on sports schools]</ref> And by 1991, some 6,000 sports schools functioned in the USSR.
== Criticism ==
Sports schools, especially the Olympic reserve ones have been in the spotlight of several scandals related to child abuse. In their strive to get the best out of children, a lot of coaches resort to verbal abuse as well as severe and sometimes sadistic physical punishments. The situation is even worse in sports boarding schools where parents exercise little control and children are fully under the coaches' authority.
Another disadvantage of this system is that much more attention is paid to sports than school education. Sports boarding schools of Olympic reserve received the sarcastic nickname "hit-and-run" ({{lang-ru|бей-беги}}; not be confused with a traffic accident or a baseball play), meaning that children mostly hit footballs and ran around sports fields instead of studying.
==Sports schools in post-Soviet states== After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union|break-up of the USSR]], the system of children and youth sports in Russia passed through difficult times, but managed to retain the network of sports schools, and Physical Training Clubs (DYuKFP) were created in addition to them.
In 2005 some 4,951 sports schools and DYuKFPs functioned in the system of education and in the system of Rossport. To the former belonged 2,944 institutions of physical culture and sports education: 1,917 sports schools, 464 Specialized sports schools of the Olympic Reserve, 556 DYuKFPs and 7 centers for physical culture. Only sports schools of the system of education were attended by some 2 million children and youth,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ed.gov.ru/files/materials/1635/Sved_ob_uchregd.doc |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716060824/http://www.ed.gov.ru/files/materials/1635/Sved_ob_uchregd.doc |archivedate=2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> and they had more than 13,000 departments in 122 sports disciplines. Rossport institutions were attended by some one million young athletes.
==Sports schools in other countries== [[File:Singapore Sports School 20, Jul 07.JPG|thumb|200px|right|[[Singapore Sports School]] ]] Soviet experience of mass children and youth sports education was applied by Eastern Europe an countries, in particular East Germany, where they were called ''Kinder- und Jugendsportschule (KJS)''<ref>{{cite book | last = Naul | first = Roland |author2=Hardman, Ken | title = Sport and Physical Education in Germany | pages = 61 | year = 2002 | publisher = [[Routledge]] | url = https://books.google.com/books?q=suitable+entry+children+youth+KJS | isbn = 0-419-25390-4}}</ref> for instance, [[Katarina Witt]] and [[Sven Fischer]] attended such schools. Similar sports schools were established in the [[People's Republic of China]], [[North Korea]] and [[Cuba]] (called Schools for Sports Initiation there),<ref>{{cite news | last = Rhoden | first = William C. | title = PAN AMERICAN GAMES; The Secret of Cuba's Sports Success? Spot the Children Who Are Athletes | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = 1991-08-19 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CEFD9133FF93AA2575BC0A967958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | accessdate = 2008-03-21}}</ref> allowing these countries to raise the level of sportsmen and achieve highest results at World Championships and Olympic Games.
At the present time some 3,000 sports schools exist in the People's Republic of China, including full-time ones, and this system is essentially based on the powerful system of sports schools of the USSR.<ref name="Rev"/>
There are a number of sports schools in Asian countries. These include [[Singapore Sports School]] in Singapore and [[Bukit Jalil Sports School]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia. Both of these schools were established after end of the Soviet Union (1991).
==See also== *[[Voluntary Sports Societies of the Soviet Union]] *[http://www.livinsport.com -LivinSport, a service for sports academies]

[[File:Fosters last message dear friends and gentle hearts.PNG|thumb|This is considered to be Stephen Foster's last message, 1863-1864, found in his wallet when he died. It bears the words "Dear friends and gentle hearts" in his handwriting. It may have been an idea for a song.]]
The '''Stephen Foster Collection and archives''' are the largest collection of primary source materials on the life and work of [[Stephen Foster]]. The collection consists of documents and other items of historical interest related to the life and work of Stephen Foster. It resides in the [[Stephen Foster Memorial]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. Josiah K. Lilly donated an almost complete set of first edition music.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stephen Foster Memorial Plans|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/101104984/|accessdate=25 October 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=14 January 1934}}</ref> The memorial houses [[Stephen Foster's sketchbook|sketchbooks]] and other memorbilia <ref>{{cite web|url=http://triblive.com//x/pittsburghtrib/ae/music/s_631281.html#axzz3ofoKMCZ6|title=Stephen Foster really did write songs the whole world sang|work=TribLIVE.com| postscript=: Access provided by the [[University of Pittsburgh Library System]]}}</ref> The process of assembling the collection was methodical, well-organized and funded by various non-governmental and governmental sources. The cost of maintaining the collection is partially funded by the University of Pittsburgh. <!-- {{Quote box|width=30em|align=left|quote=Stephen Foster died at age 37 in New York City. When he was found he only had his wallet in which a scrap of paper was found with the words "Dear Friends, and Gentle Hearts" written on it |image=File:Fosters last message dear friends and gentle hearts.png|[[File:Fosters last message dear friends and gentle hearts.PNG|thumb|This is considered to be Stephen Foster's last message, 1863-1864, found in his wallet when he died. It bears the words "Dear friends and gentle hearts" in his handwriting. It may have been an idea for a song.]]}} -->
== History ==
The Stephen Foster archives are housed in the Stephen Foster Memorial which was designed by architect [[Charles Klauder]]. Its construction reflects the same style as the [[Cathedral of Learning]], and [[Heinz Chapel]] on the University of Pittsburgh's campus. The W.F. Trimble & Son's Company was contracted to help erect the building on March 2, 1935.<ref name=lilly>{{cite web | title = Untitled Document | url = http://www.pitt.edu/~amerimus/AboutCollection.html | accessdate = 2015-10-27 }}</ref> It consists of {{convert|35000|cuft|m3}} of Indiana limestone, 400 [[short ton|tons]] (360,000 kg) of steel, and {{convert|2500|cuyd|m3}} of concrete.<ref name=lilly/> In 1930, Josiah Kirby Lilly began collecting all forms of Foster's music, letters, furniture, original manuscripts and instruments. He kept his collection in his own stone cottage in Indianapolis. He called it Foster Hall. Then in 1932 Josiah Kirby Lilly pledged more than 10,000 Foster items to form the initial archive collection. Other efforts began the necessary fund-raising. Lily and his son covered almost half of the cost at that time amounting to $550,000.<ref name=tribmem>{{cite web | title = Theater: A dramatic makeover for the Stephen Foster Memorial | url = http://old.post-gazette.com/ae/20030330randall3.asp |first=Patricia |last=Lowry|date= 30 March 2003|publisher= Pittsburgh Post Gazette | accessdate = 2015-10-25 }}</ref> A portion of the collection has now been digitized and can be accessed through the University of Pittsburgh's [[Hillman Library#University Library System|University Library System]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Foster Hall Collection |work=Guide to Archives and Manuscript Collections at the University of Pittsburgh Library System | url = http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/f/findaid/findaid-idx?type=simple;c=ascead;view=reslist;subview=standard;didno=US-PPiU-camfhc201101 | accessdate = 2015-10-25 }}</ref>
== Methodology ==
Establishing the scope of Stephen Foster music and discography was conducted by Dr. Deane Root, the curator of the Stephen C. Foster Memorial at the University of Pittsburgh. He initiated the revision of the standard reference work on Stephen Foster music - "Songs and Compositions and Arrangements by Stephen Collins Foster 1826-1864" published in 1933.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wittlesey|first1=Walter|last2=Sonneck|first2=O,G.|title=Songs and Compostions and arrangements by Stephen Collins Foster 1826-1864|date=1915|publisher=Washington, Government Printing Office|location=Washington, D.C.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2VcWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=Horace+Waters+hymn&source=bl&ots=jMztTuOQVb&sig=xhWVLhrULl2mSFvpXvc2Cc61V80&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBmoVChMImJKF_fXayAIVQ2w-Ch1aqwaP#v=onepage&q=Horace%20Waters%20hymn&f=false|accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref> The new reference work, published with the Smithsonian Institution Press was assisted by the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archive of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, New York City. At the time of the drafting of the new discography, other archives were reviewed. These were Stanford University, Stanford, CA; Yale University, New Haven, CT; Library of Congress, Washington, DC; Rodgers and Hammerstein Archive, Lincoln Center, New York City; and Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY, and the Library of Congress, Music Division. Creating the new discography was aided by collectors throughout the United States and in foreign countries. These loaned their own catalogs, listed out specific records in their collections, and supplied other known listings. The examination of private, commercial auction lists and other retail mail offerings were also used to identify Foster pieces for purchase and to compare to the other listings.<ref name=Creegan/>
In updating the 1933 discography, Roote employed other materials. Slips came with the early-unmarked cylinders, and were often hand-written. These written descriptions were not attached to the cylinders themselves. This was not the case for labels pressed on a disc recordings which were badly deteriorated.<ref name=Creegan/>
One the collections notable recordings was a brown Wax Cylinder (c.1895) from Wheeling, WV. This recording by the vocalist Edward M. Favor is one of the earliest recordings in the archives. Its volume is faint and was intended to be used with a tube and earphone type machine. Historians assume that not more than 50 pieces were made of this cylinder.<ref name=Creegan/>
Research into creating a new, authoritative and complete discography included the review of marketing materials of the Edison Amberol record supplements were published every month from 1906 to the 1920s by the Edison Record sales staff in Orange, NJ, The purpose of the promotional materials was to keep the public and recording retailers up to date on the newest Edison releases. Edison's company wanted to appeal to as wide an audience as possible. His marketing materials were helpful in expanding the discography and identified marches by Sousa, a recitation by Davenport), violin solos by Spaulding, orchestra selections such as Herbert's Operetta Little Nemo, and a ballad by tenor Will Oakland (''Just Before the Battle Mother'').<ref name=Creegan/>
Though today recording companies are generally cooperative, creating a comprehensive discography was hampered by the usual business practices of controlling costs and the lack of financial incentives in the preservation of commercial record companies. At the time that a recording was made, it was not viewed as "a creation of recorded history", and files were maintained for "commercial control". Recording companies have not been found to support research into their own history in house or by outside researchers. For example, Columbia Records, established in the 1890s has little information on the thousands of cylinder recordings it sold.<ref name=Creegan/>
== Discography ==
The Stephen Foster archives are housed in the [[Stephen Foster Memorial]] on the campus of the [[University of Pittsburgh]], also the location of the Center For American Music (Pittsburgh). The contents were collected by various organizations and individuals who conducted their efforts between 1896 and 1925. The collection includes the acoustic recordings made in US during these years and are cataloged in a discography. This list describes the over 450 published and 32 unpublished acoustic recordings. In addition to the recording themselves, the collection documents biographical details along with accompanying photographs of the musicians, groups, vocalists and music publishers who performed or sold Foster's music.
The recordings were transferred from original cylinders and record albumns. The cylinders are of various speed, speeds and manufacture and origin. They are made of both wax and celluloid. The cylinders are recordings of songs that are from two and four minutes long (some longer). The long playing albumns (70 rpm), made of shellac, of the music were also transferred to audio cassettes. Disc recordings range from five to 12 inches. <!-- Hillandale and lateral cut --> Player piano rolls and music box perforated discs were also used at the time to play Foster's music, although these are not part of the collection.<ref name=Creegan/>
Contributors to the collection include: Creegan, The Association of Recorded Sound Collections (ARSC).<ref name=Creegan>{{cite journal|last1=Creegan|first1=George C.|title=The Acoustic Recordings of Stephen C. Foster|journal=ARSC Journal|date=Fall 2002|volume=33|issue=2|pages=214-228|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/968993/|accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref>
== Holdings ==
The Foster Hall Collection contains many primary sources: {{div col|colwidth=15em}}
* his Bible<ref>{{cite web|title=Holy Bible (Philadelphia: E.H. Butler & Co.), 1854 Foster Hall Collection, CAM.FHC.2011.01, Center for American Music, University of Pittsburgh|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735066205935.pdf#|accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref> * music manuscripts<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * [[Stephen Foster's sketchbook|Stephen Foster's bound sketchbook]]<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * his bound account book<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * his personal and family correspondence<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * musical instruments<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * business records<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * photographs<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * newspaper clippings<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * his manuscript material<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * correspondence<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * personal possessions<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * his autograph<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * personal books owned by Foster<ref>{{cite web|title=Walker's Dictionary, Foster Hall Collection, CAM.FHC.2011.01, Center for American Music, University of Pittsburgh |url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735066205844.pdf|accessdate=25 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=National Melodies of Scotland United to the Songs of Robert Burns, Allan Ramsay and Other Eminent Lyric Poets with Symphonies and Accompaniments for the Pianoforte by Haydn, Pleyel, Lozeluch (London; New York; John & Frederick Tallis), 1849|url =http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735066205885.pdf |accessdate=26 October 2015 }}</ref> * sheet music * musical instruments<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * Foster's prayer book<ref>{{cite web|title=Nouveau Petit Paroissien (Tours: Mam et Cie), 1855 Foster Hall Collection, CAM.FHC.2011.01, Center for American Music, University of Pittsburgh. |url =http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735066205877.pdf |accessdate= 25 October 2015}}</ref> * Eight-keyed rosewood flute<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * Standard nineteenth-century six-octave square piano with rosewood case<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * Three-octave instrument with oak case. Features knee bellows, detachable legs and shoulder straps for portability when serenading<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * wedding gifts<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * hospital documents<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * Telegram informing Foster's family of his death<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * images of Foster<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * photos of Foster<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * hand-written music manuscripts by Foster<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * Foster's commercial ledger<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * autographs, poems by Foster<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * contracts<!-- <ref>{{cite web|title= |url = |accessdate= }}</ref> --> * the well-known scrap of paper found in Foster's wallet after his death with the words "Dear friends and gentle hearts" in his autograph.<ref>{{cite web|title=Foster's last message, 1863-1864Foster Hall Collection, CAM.FHC.2011.01 |url =http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735066205745.pdf |accessdate=26 October 2015 }}</ref> * telegraph to Morrison Foster informing him of Stephen's death<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Union Telegram reporting Foster's death, Jan. 14, 1864Foster Hall Collection, CAM.FHC.2011.01, Center for American Music |url =http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735061821660.pdf |accessdate=26 October 2015 }}</ref>
{{div col end}}
== Biographical materials ==
The resources of the collection have been used by numerous biographers.<ref>{{cite web| title = Stephen Collins Foster, Introduction to Pictorial Biography| url = http://www.bobjanuary.com/foster/sf1.htm| accessdate = 2015-11-07 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Stephen Foster}} {{University of Pittsburgh Library System Archives and Collections}}

page.title: The West Sussex Grid for Learning

revision.text:
{{COI|date=August 2010}}
The '''West Sussex Grid for Learning''' (WSGfL) was launched by [[West Sussex]] [[County Council]] (WSCC), as part of the [[National Grid for Learning]] initiative. The National Grid for Learning (NGfL) was a [[United Kingdom]] Government-funded gateway to educational resources on the [[Internet]]. It featured many individually selected links to resources and materials deemed to be of high quality.
At the time of the launch, the WSGfL website was dedicated to the learning community of West Sussex - which included teachers, pupils, non-teaching staff and parents. However, the WSGfL is now much more. The WSGfL provides a filtered [[broadband]] connection, network services, online content and communities for all schools across West Sussex.
== South East Grid for Learning (SEGfL) ==
The South East Grid for Learning (SEGfL) covers a large geographical area. It is a populous consortium with over eight million residents and seventeen very different Local Authorities. SEGfL has 3,121 schools with 56,800 [[teachers]] and over 1,000,000 pupils.
SEGfL includes Bracknell Forest Borough Council, Brighton & Hove City Council, Buckinghamshire County Council, East Sussex County Council, Hampshire County Council, Isle of Wight Council, Kent County Council, Medway Council, Portsmouth City Council, Reading Borough Council, Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead, Slough Borough Council, Southampton City Council, Surrey County Council, West Berkshire Council, West Sussex County Council and Wokingham District Council.
== Contact ==
The WSGfL is managed and developed by the ICT Strategy & Initiatives team who are part of Children & Young People's Services at WSCC.
==External links== * [http://wsgfl.westsussex.gov.uk West Sussex Grid for Learning] * [http://www.segfl.org.uk South East Grid for Learning]
{{DEFAULTSORT:West Sussex Grid For Learning}} [[Category:Governmental educational technology organizations]] [[Category:Education in West Sussex]] [[Category:Organisations based in West Sussex]]
